p:
The intensity of surveillance could also potentially vary across subtypes and lineages. The mean age of infection for A/H3 is greater than influenza B
46 viruses, and healthcare-seeking behaviour may differ between adults, parents with children and children. Furthermore, it is commonly thought that A/H3 virus infections result in more severe clinical presentations and greater risk of mortality
47 than influenza B viruses, potentially resulting in differences in the likelihood of detection by a sentinel health practitioner, though this may not be the case (see ref.
48 ).
